title: Ronald Koeman hopes old club Southampton LOSE EFL Cup final to hand Everton a European boost
text:
Sport Ronald Koeman hopes old club Southampton LOSE EFL Cup final to hand Everton a European boost The Dutchman spent two years in charge at St Mary's, but would like his former charges to come up short on Sunday Share Koeman wants to take the Toffees into Europe (Photo: Getty Images Europe) Share Get football   Could   
Everton manager Ronald Koeman hopes former club Southampton LOSE in Sunday’s EFL Cup final. 
The Dutchman spent two years as coach at St Mary’s before walking out to join the Toffees in the summer. 
And despite his former allegiance to the south coast side, Koeman will not be supporting them when they meet Manchester United at Wembley - due to his own European hopes. 
Everton currently sit seventh in the Premier League and Koeman knows that a victory for Jose Mourinho’s men will boost his sides continental hopes. 
A seventh place finish this season could net the Toffees a Europa League spot, provided United are successful on Sunday and a side above Koeman’s Merseysiders also wins the FA Cup. Koeman wants to see his successor defeated on Sunday (Photo: Mike Hewitt / Getty) 
As such, with the potential benefits that European football bring, in terms of being able to attract players, Koeman is hoping for a favour from United. 
"It is true you need help from which team will win the EFL Cup or the FA Cup,” said Koeman. 
"In that way we hope United will win at the weekend and one of biggest clubs wins the FA Cup, because then it's possible seventh in the table can play for qualification for the Europa League. 
"Players like to be part of Europe, and like to be part of Champions League. That is the best for football players, but that will normally be impossible. Koeman with Everton fan Tony Bellew earlier this week 
"The first step is to be part of Europe even if it being part of a difficult European league on Thursday or qualification really soon in the pre-season. We would like to do it and be part of it because Europe is the next step. 
"Some players were interested, but ok, maybe also some like to see how we progressed in Everton for the future. You will always fight against big clubs with more reputation and with more Champions League competition.
